5/5) Your implementation of a tactical execution plan will be how you take your product/service to market through different channels such as public relations, digital marketing (e.g. social media, SEO), influencer marketing, and traditional marketing

4/5) Your development of an internal marketing strategy will include the following 5 key steps: 1. Define Your Market 2. Confirm Your Value 3. Segment Your Customers 4. Identify Your Unique Selling Proposition 5. Position Your Brand
3/5) Your “Why” or reason for existence (e.g., purpose, cause, or belief) should live at the core of all your marketing efforts and guide the creation of your brand Mission, Vision, and Values
2/5) We break down the marketing process into three high-level steps: 1. Know Your “Why” 2. Align on a Marketing Strategy 3. Develop a Tactical Plan and Execute

New Blog Post Alert: As a founder launching your startup, you’ll face the challenge of how to market your product or service. We wanted to provide internal and external marketing strategies for early-stage founders. Check out the post below

Another question often asked is, “Can Your Start-up Return ‘The Fund’? We wanted to provide insight to how our fund model works, 5 steps 1) Check Size 2) Valuation 3) Dilution 4) Exit Price 5) Exit Returns as % of Fund

Awesome insights on diversity in Fortune 100 companies by @StanfordGSB. The increase in diversity has largely been a gender conversation as little progress has been made for POC https://www.gsb.stanford.edu/sites/gsb/files/publication-pdf/cgri-2020-diversity-in-c-suite.pdf

Investors, Robert Smith says, “You should be a MASTER of your craft.” Math is a part of venture, there is no way around it as this is still investing. You may have a network, empathy, proprietary deal flow, but have the math as well. OWN your craft

Founders, we encourage you to think through this math so you are aligned w/ investors. We also encourage you to run this math for your own equity. Too often we see founders w/ too little equity early on. Some insight can really help protect the thing you are working so hard on

First, why wait 1-2 Decades??? What you learn today won’t be as relevant in 10-20 years. The iPhone was launched 13 years ago, whole different world - read and listen to as much as possible. @HarryStebbings is best - get reps of reviewing decks - develop your top theses

10/10: By 2050, 90% of U.S. population is estimated to be urban, up from 80% today. 88% of jobs are in metro areas, putting pressure on housing prices and public transit and driving gentrification. It remains to be seen if COVID-19 will alter this trend

9/10: Income inequality has widened dramatically. CEO compensation grew by 1,008% from 1978-2018 vs. 12% for the avg worker, and the gap between wealthiest and poorest families grew >2x in >30 years. The racial income gap has not narrowed with the narrowing of the education gap

8/10: AI and automation are expected to be net job creators, but new jobs will be largely STEM, which will hurt Black and Latinx workers (currently only 9% and 7% of STEM workforce). Impacts will also vary widely by location--by 2030 60% of job growth will be in 25 major cities

7/10: The median age at 1st marriage increased to 29 (M) and 27 (W), and 15% of new marriages are among people of different races (up 2x since 1980). Pets are seen as family more than ever--there are now more households with pets than children (43M vs. 33M)

6/10: Women still lag men in earnings, leadership roles & wealth, despite earning more undergrad degrees than men & comprising 51% of college-educated workers. Women are the primary breadwinner in 40% of families but still spend ~2x time caregiving time vs. men

5/10: As of 2019, Millennials are the largest adult generation in the U.S. They are more diverse (43% non-White) & better-educated than predecessors, but $8k average net worth is far lower than prior generations due to student loans, high housing prices, healthcare costs

4/10: Hispanics are the most economically influential group since Baby Boomers. They are 18% of U.S. population but contributed 70% of recent labor force growth, & Hispanic-owned businesses have grown more than 2x the rate of all U.S. businesses since 2012

3/10: By 2034, an aging population of adults 65+ will outnumber children for the 1st time. The 65+ population will double by 2060 as people live longer. Americans 55+ drive 42% of consumer spending, almost double the next-largest spending group

2/10: There is a looming consumer debt crisis as the $14T balance now exceeds 2008 peak. Younger & minority borrowers are heavily burdened with unsecured debt. For ages 18-29: ~35% of debt is student loans, ~35% mortgages

1/10: The new consumer cares about experiences > things and is asset-light. Women & minorities heavily influence spending--Hispanic purchasing power has grown 70% faster than Americans’ overall since the 80s & women drive 85% of consumer purchases

Methodology - “From our 1,700 founders, we sliced the top 200 raises by female founders, which included 13 Black and Latina founders, and combined that data with the next top 100 raises by Black and Latina founders. These 300 women are our Pacesetters”

14/ Shout out to the top 10 companies: @creditkarma @KabbageInc @Sunnova_Solar @CommonBond @Sunrun @23andMe @HorizonRoboticz @houzz Top 12 Investors: @NEA @ycombinator @500Startups @GVteam @sequoia @kleinerperkins @KaporCapital @ComcastVentures @a16z @firstround @svangel
13/ You can find the full report on our website with the list of the top 300 female founder raises

12/ In conclusion, the VC ecosystem has become more female-founder friendly, but it’s important to understand these trailblazing leaders not simply as a monolithic group. They are a diverse coalition with varying backgrounds, industries, geographies, and education levels

11/ Out of 805 investors total, the top 12 made 172 investments in 66% of companies. These investors include two accelerators, one angel syndicate, and one corporate venture capital fund, in addition to eight “traditional” VCs

10/ The top 10 largest raises represent 44% of all capital raised by these 300 founders. The top three raises (Credit Karma at $7bn, Kabbage at $2.5bn, and Sunnova at $2.4bn), represent 25% of all capital raised. The skew to a few in venture remains true for female founders

9/ Further, just 10 graduate programs represent 59% of all capital raised by the top 300 female founders. The top graduate programs by company count are Harvard Business School, Harvard University, and Wharton

8/ 25% of female-founded startups are represented by just 8 undergraduate universities. The top three undergraduate institutions by company count are Harvard University, Stanford University, and Cornell University

7/ Notably, graduate degrees are most common among women of color. 46% of Asian American women, 40% of African American female founders, and 26% of Latina women have an MBA, as compared to just 23% of white female founders
6/ 85% held the CEO or founder title and 77% had at least 1 co-founder
5/ 54 founders have raised Seed, but 123 have raised Series B and post-B funding. Also 21% have successfully exited so far, showing significant traction for female founders
4/ There were 28 cities represented with SF and NYC representing 57% of companies and 56% of capital. Medians varied across cities

3/There were 26 different industries represented with the top three being biotech, e-commerce, and software, encompassing 40% of companies. Financial services, biotech, and industrials & energy were top of capital raised at 45%

2/ 300 Pacesetters: We then took a deep dive into the top 200 female founders and top 100 Black and Latina founders to identify key trends by race. Out of the top 300 founders, 52% are white, 16% are Asian, 18% are African American, and 16% are Latina

Key Insights from the report 1/ We analyzed 1,714 female founders from 1,551 companies that raised $56.4bn of VC funding. The average company was founded in 2013 and raised $5.8mm. Over 50% latest funding was a Seed or Series A Round
Excited to share that the report is now live

In conclusion, we often hear that it’s difficult to find diverse founders. We hope this report can serve as a guide to who those founders are, what cities they’re concentrated in, as well as the variety of industries they’re disrupting. Check out the full report for all companies

7) There were 567 investors across the 182 companies. Leading the pack are 12 investors who invested in 149 of the 182 companies. Should be noted that 5 of the top 12 firms have diverse GPs, with 3 of those 5 having a diversity-focused thesis
6) The top 10 represented $3.7bn or 62% of capital raised, which is similar to the overall venture landscape as later stage funding takes the lion share of funding

5) The average company was founded in 2013 and 2012 founded companies represented 44% of capital raised. The median raise for companies less than 4 years old is $2mm compared to $12mm for companies older than 4 years. There should be a pop in the median for 2015 companies coming

4) There were 28 cities represented but NYC, SF and LA represented 65% of the sample and 76% of the capital raised. The median raise is pretty consistent in the top markets and other cities like ATL, BOS and DC are emerging for diverse founders

3) There were over 18 industries represented with Software, Media and Healthcare representing 43% of the sample, but only 16% of capital raised as Real Estate was 30% as a result of @Compass and @CadreRE
2) African American males represented 46% of the sample size and 56% of the capital raised. Men raised 3.0x as much the women founders with Latino Men raising $11mm

Key Insights from the report 1) Overall there were 200 founders from 182 companies that raised $6bn of VC funding. The average company was founded in 2013 and raised $5mm. 84% were CEOs or Co-Founders and 58% latest funding was a Seed Round
